docs.title: Git Metrics MCP Server
docs.text: MCP server for analyzing git repository metrics and understanding team health.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: npm install -g @jonmatum/git-metrics-mcp-server

docs.title: Kiro CLI Configuration
docs.text:
Add to ~/.kiro/settings/mcp.json:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "git-metrics": {
      "command": "git-metrics-mcp-server",
      "args": []
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
kiro-cli chat

Ask natural language questions: 

Get commit stats for /home/user/myproject since 2025-11-01
Show me team summary for the last 2 weeks
What's our bus factor?

docs.title: Git Metrics Analysis Prompt
docs.text: Use this prompt with Kiro CLI to generate comprehensive team activity reports for any repository collection.

docs.title: Prompt
docs.text:
Use my git-metrics MCP server to analyze team health and development patterns across all repositories in this path.

IMPORTANT: This analysis is for team reflection, process improvement, and risk management—NOT individual performance evaluation. Focus on collaboration patterns, sustainable practices, and code quality trends.

Include:
- Team collaboration patterns and file sharing
- Bus factor and knowledge distribution risks
- Work-life balance indicators (weekend/late-night commits)
- Code quality trends (commit size, revert rate, fix rate)
- Velocity trends and sustainable pace
- Technical debt hotspots (stale files, high churn)
- Release discipline and conventional commit adoption
- Cross-team collaboration patterns

Generate a comprehensive markdown report with:
1. Executive summary highlighting team health
2. Repository-level insights on collaboration and quality
3. Risk identification (bus factor, technical debt)
4. Process improvement recommendations (not individual critiques)
5. Team health score and best practices to replicate

Frame all findings as conversation starters for team improvement, not as judgments of individual performance.

Analyze from 2024-01-01 to present.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the directory containing your repositories: 

    cd /path/to/your/repos

  2. Start Kiro CLI: 

    kiro-cli chat

  3. Paste the prompt above

  4. The analysis will be saved as team-activity-analysis.md in the current directory

docs.title: Customization
docs.text:
To analyze a different time period, modify the prompt: 

Analyze from YYYY-MM-DD to present.

To focus on specific repositories: 

Focus the analysis on these repositories: repo1, repo2, repo3

To change the output filename, add: 

Save the report as custom-report-name.md

docs.title: MCP Server Requirements
docs.text:
Ensure the git-metrics MCP server is configured in your Kiro CLI setup with these capabilities:

  • get_team_summary
  • get_code_ownership
  • get_velocity_trends
  • get_quality_metrics
  • get_collaboration_metrics
  • get_commit_patterns
  • get_technical_debt
  • get_file_churn
  • get_conventional_commits

docs.title: What This Tool Is For
docs.text: This MCP server provides objective data for better conversations, not surveillance metrics for micromanagement.

docs.title: ✅ Good Use Cases
docs.text:
Sprint Retrospectives - "What did we accomplish this sprint?" - "Where did we spend most of our time?" - Saves 15-30 minutes of manual git log parsing

Code Quality Insights - "Which files are changing most frequently?" (high churn = potential issues) - "Where should we focus code reviews?" - "Do we have technical debt hotspots?"

Team Health Monitoring - "Are people committing late at night or on weekends?" (burnout indicator) - "Is work distributed evenly or is someone overwhelmed?" - Early warning signs for proactive intervention

Risk Management - "What's our bus factor?" (knowledge concentration) - "Who's the only person who knows this critical code?" - Succession planning and knowledge sharing

Onboarding Tracking - "How is the new developer ramping up?" - Objective data for coaching conversations - Identify where they need more support

docs.title: ❌ What This Is NOT For
docs.text:
Micromanagement - ❌ Checking individual commit counts daily - ❌ Comparing developers against each other - ❌ Using metrics as performance review ammunition - ❌ Surveillance or "productivity monitoring"

Performance Evaluation - ❌ Commits ≠ value delivered - ❌ Lines of code ≠ quality - ❌ Activity ≠ impact

docs.title: Data as Conversation Starter
docs.text:
Instead of: - ❌ "Why did you only commit 5 times this week?" - ❌ "Your velocity is down 20%" - ❌ "Bob commits more than you"

Use it for: - ✅ "I noticed high churn on auth.ts - need help?" - ✅ "Lots of late-night commits lately - too much on your plate?" - ✅ "This file has 3 authors - should we pair on it?" - ✅ "We haven't touched this module in 6 months - is it stable or forgotten?"

docs.title: Trust Over Surveillance
docs.text: This tool assumes: - Your team is competent and motivated - Context matters more than raw numbers - Trends are more valuable than snapshots - Questions are better than accusations

docs.title: Frequency Guidelines
docs.text:
Recommended: - Weekly: Quick health check (5 min) - Sprint end: Retrospective insights (15 min) - Monthly: Trend analysis (30 min) - Quarterly: Strategic review (1 hour)

Not Recommended: - Daily individual tracking - Real-time monitoring - Comparative rankings - Automated alerts on low activity

docs.title: ✅ You Should Use This If:
docs.text:
• You lead a team (3+ developers)
  • You do regular retrospectives
  • You care about code quality trends
  • You want data-driven conversations
  • You're looking for process improvements
  • You need to identify risks early

docs.title: 🚫 Skip This Tool If:
docs.text:
• Solo developer
  • Team < 3 people
  • You trust your gut more than data
  • Your team would see it as surveillance
  • You're looking for "productivity scores"
  • You want to compare developers

docs.title: Red Flags (Don't Do This)
docs.text:
If you find yourself doing any of these, stop and reconsider:

  • Checking metrics more than once per day
  • Asking "why" about individual commit counts
  • Creating leaderboards or rankings
  • Setting commit quotas or targets
  • Using metrics in performance reviews without context
  • Monitoring in real-time
  • Comparing developers directly

docs.title: Green Flags (Good Usage)
docs.text:
You're using this tool well if:

  • You check trends weekly/monthly, not daily
  • You ask "what does this tell us about our process?"
  • You use it to start conversations, not end them
  • You combine metrics with qualitative feedback
  • You focus on team health, not individual performance
  • You look for patterns, not outliers
  • You use it to help, not judge

docs.title: Good: Process Improvement
docs.text:
"I noticed auth.ts has been modified 25 times this month. 
That's unusual. Should we refactor it or is it just evolving?"

docs.title: Good: Team Support
docs.text:
"The commit patterns show a lot of weekend work lately. 
Are we overloaded? Should we adjust sprint capacity?"

docs.title: Good: Risk Management
docs.text:
"Only Sarah has touched the payment module in 6 months. 
Should we do some knowledge sharing sessions?"

docs.title: Bad: Micromanagement
docs.text:
"You only committed 3 times this week. Everyone else did 10+. 
What's going on?"

docs.title: Bad: Comparison
docs.text: "Bob's velocity is 2x yours. Why aren't you keeping up?"

docs.title: The Bottom Line
docs.text:
This tool is a mirror, not a microscope.

Use it to reflect on team health and process quality, not to scrutinize individual behavior.

If you're asking "is this micromanagement?" - you're probably safe. Micromanagers don't ask that question.

Remember: The best teams are built on trust, not metrics. Use this tool to support your team, not surveil them.
